results.title: Consumer protection
results.brief_description: A comparison of the buying habits of two American families - the Kings and the Whites. The Whites’ buying habits are based on the price and appearance of the product, while the Kings take advantage of consumer services offered in the USA, and thus make sure that they only buy the best.

results.title: Consumer power
results.creator_credit: Australian Broadcasting Corporation and Peita Bolden
results.brief_description: Four fifteen minute programs which follow Anna, Nick and skeleton Clive as they set up a toy shop and in the process learn to cope with the minefield of choices and responsibilities facing young consumers. An engaging and humourous story unfolds to assist 7-10 year olds in learning about consumer expectations, advertising, budgeting and consumer rights and responsibilities.

results.title: Consumer education: who needs it?
results.creator_credit: Richard Wallace and William C. Crain
results.brief_description: An introduction to consumer problems, especially with respect to supermarkets, car selling, advertising, and credit buying. We see both angry and unconcerned customers. The major problem areas are outlined by people working in the area of consumer protection.

results.title: Consumer education: maintaining an automobile
results.brief_description: Several young auto owners are shown dealing with the maintenance and repair requirements of their cars. The aim is to inform the viewer of the importance of proper automobile servicing and repairing and to advise how these may be accomplished with economy, emphasising the fact that proper servicing can make owning a car a pleasure.

results.title: Consumatic
results.brief_description: A product of a final year research project from the Victoria University of Technology (VUT) Advanced Diploma of Arts (Electronic Design and Interactive Media) course. Consumatic is a dystopic view of consumerism structured around a journey through the urban environment of Melbourne.

results.title: Construction Play (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Ann Sharp, Kathleen Manning, Drake Educational Associates and Ward Lock Educational
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Structuring Play in the Infant School No.3”.
Shows the different kinds of stimuli that are the basis of the children’s play. Construction play covers play with large and small building material both manufactured and improvised; sometimes these are combined with other materials e.g. sand

results.title: Construction history: Chesapeake Bay Bridge Tunnel
results.brief_description: A film record of the building of the seventeen and a half mile, US$200,000,000 bridge-tunnel crossing of lower Chesapeake Bay in Northern America. The bridge-tunnel will connect the eastern shore of Virginia with Norfolk area, forming a link in the Ocean Highway and replacing the existing ferry service. The project comprises two trench type tunnels, four man-made islands, twelve miles of low level trestles and two high level fixed steel bridges and an earth-filled causeway. It all began in 1957 when the first tests were started and was eventually completed on 15th April 1964 when the official opening took place.

results.title: Constructing social reality
results.creator_credit: David Espar, Tuggelin Yourgrau and WGBH (Boston)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 20 of Series “Discovering psychology”.
In this episode, Philip Zimbardo of Stanford University, shows how far our subjective view of reality forms the foundation of most of our social behaviour and how people develop beliefs to make sense of the world around them. Jane Elliot’s 1968 experiment in artificially generating discrimination in a class of third grade students is shown. By dividing the class into superior “blue-eyes” and inferior “brown-eyes” she showed how easily objective reality can be distorted.
